sass 0.2.0.9003

Get and set the default cache used for compiled css files

Source: R/sass_cache.R
sass_cache_get.Rd

The default cache is used by the sass() function to cache outputs. In some cases when developing and modifying .scss files, sass() might not detect changes, and keep using cached .css files instead of rebuilding them. To be safe, if you are developing a theme with sass, it's best to turn off caching by setting cache to NULL.

sass_cache_get()

sass_cache_set(cache = sass_file_cache())

Arguments

cache

A sass_file_cache() object, or NULL if you don't want to use a cache.

Details

If caching is enabled, sass() will attempt to bypass the compilation process by reusing output from previous sass() calls that used equivalent inputs. This mechanism works by computing a cache key from each sass() call's input, option, and cache_key_extra arguments. If an object with that hash already exists within the cache directory, its contents are used instead of performing the compilation. If it does not exist, then compilation is performed and usual and the results are stored in the cache.

If a file that is included using sass_file() changes on disk (i.e. its last-modified time changes), its previous cache entries will effectively be invalidated (not removed from disk, but they'll no longer be matched). However, if a file imported using sass_file() itself imports other sass files using @import, changes to those files are invisible to the cache and you will end up with stale results. Caching should be disabled in cases like this.

If sass_cache_get() is called before sass_cache_set(), then it will create a cache in a subdirectory of the system temp directory named R-sass-cache-username and set it as the default. Because this cache directory is not in the R process's temp directory, it will persist longer than the R process, typically until a system reboot. Additionally, it will be shared across R processes for the same user on the same system.

By default, the maximum size of the cache is 40 MB. If it grows past that size, the least-recently-used objects will be evicted from the cache to keep it under that size. To set the options for the cache, create a FileCache object and set it as the default cache.

To clear the cache (but keep using it in the future), call sass_cache_get()$reset().

See also

sass_file_cache

Examples

# Very slow to compile
fib_sass <- "@function fib($x) {
  @if $x <= 1 {
    @return $x
  }
  @return fib($x - 2) + fib($x - 1);
}

body {
  width: fib(27);
}"

# The first time this runs it will be very slow
system.time(sass(fib_sass))

#>    user  system elapsed 
#>   8.468   0.057   8.699 

# But on subsequent calls, it should be very fast
system.time(sass(fib_sass))

#>    user  system elapsed 
#>   0.003   0.001   0.004 

# sass() can be called with cache=NULL; it will be slow
system.time(sass(fib_sass, cache = NULL))

#>    user  system elapsed 
#>   8.698   0.056   9.076 

# Clear the cache
sass_cache_get()$reset()

if (FALSE) {
# Example of disabling cache by setting the default cache to NULL.

# Disable the default cache (save the original one first, so we can restore)
old_cache <- sass_cache_get()
sass_cache_set(NULL)
# Will be slow, because no cache
system.time(sass(fib_sass))

# Restore the original cache
sass_cache_set(old_cache)
}
